InfoVis - D3

  • Introduction
  • D3 manipulate DOM
  • D3 Data Binding
  • D3 DOM transition
  • References

  1. Introduction

    D3 is a javascript framework for data visualization in web (broswer environment).

    D3 can directly read and parse .cvs file (Microsoft Excel), and store it as a JS Object.

    D3 can dynamically generate SVG graphics.

    D3 can manipulate DOM objects.

    d3.select-chain.[specify-data].[transition-chain].[action-chain]

  2. D3 manipulate DOM

    d3.[select*].[action]

                d3.selectAll("p").style("color", "white");
            d3.select("body").style("background-color", "black");
            d3.select('#example-1').selectAll('p').style("color", "green");
            d3.select('#example-2').selectAll('p').style("font-size", (d, i)=>{
                // i is index from 0, to the number of p - 1.
                // a map high order function.
                return i * 3;
            });

    id = example-1

    Another p tag

    id = example-2

    Another p tag

  3. D3 Data Binding (data-driven DOM)

    d3.[select*].data([...]).[action]

    d3.[select*].data([...]).enter().append('p').[action]

    d3.[select*].data([...]).exit().remove()

    The number of data and the number of DOM should be equal. Otherwise, it depends on the smaller one.

    To avoid this happen, use .enter() and .exit().
    .enter().append('dom').[action] means for the remaining data that cannot find DOM, append '' for them and act // the action only has affect on the redundant data.
    .exit().remove() remove the redundant elements 

                // common pattern
            var p = d3.select("body")
            .selectAll("p")
            .data([4, 8, 15, 16, 23, 42])
                .text(function(d) { return d; });

            // Enter…
            p.enter().append("p")
                .text(function(d) { return d; });

            // Exit…
            p.exit().remove();
        
                d3.select('#example-3').selectAll('p')
                .data([4, 5]).text((d, i)=>{
                // d is the bound data
                return d + 'px';
            });

    10

    10

    10

                d3.select('#example-4').selectAll('p')
                .data([4, 5]).exit().remove();

    1

    2

    3

                d3.select('#example-5').selectAll('p')
                .data([4, 5, 7, 8]).enter().append('p').text(d=>{return d;});

    1

    3

  4. D3 Transition

    d3.[select*].transition().[action]

    d3.[select*].transition().[transition-type()].[action]

                d3.select('#example-6').transition().style('background-color', 'black');
            d3.selectAll('#example-6 p').transition().style('color', 'white');

    Example-6 Fade to black
